context: Immunotoxicology studies in contaminant-exposed mammals describe both antibody mediated immunosuppression, plus thymic and splenic atrophy (Kennedy et al., 2004; Peden-Adams et al., 2008). Yet in quail exposed to the same contaminant, perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), of the four immunotoxicity tests including a disease challenge, only the T cell response was suppressed (Smits and Nain, 2013), which raises the possibility that Japanese quail are a relatively insensitive species. From this study we cannot determine if specific contaminants affected the birds or if it was the mixture of compounds. The long-term effects of NO2 and SO2 emitted from a coal-fired power plant were described for two species of passerines (a different order than quail and kestrels) and one rodent species. These animals were kept for 6 months in outdoor cages 2km from the power plant. Average concentrations over 5 months were 0.1ppm for SO2 and 0.006ppm NO2. For these exposed birds, the tracheas had excessive mucus and shorter cilia compared to controls.
